title: peter stringfellow nightclub king princess diana london
story: When I interviewed Peter Stringfellow three years ago he told me that he reckoned he had 10 years left to live.Sadly, he was out by seven.The legendary lap-dancing magnate died yesterday at the age of 77 after a battle with cancer.A flamboyant and charismatic character, he packed far more into life than most and is said to have left a &pound37million fortune.lornajanenewmanYesterday the tributes were flooding in from his celebrity friends                Peter Stringfellow dead: Who was Peter Stringfellow? What was he worthInstantly identifiable thanks to his peroxide mullet &ndash which gave way to a mane of grey in later life &ndash his &ldquogentlemen&rsquos clubs were a magnet for City boys, pop singers and soap stars.A lifelong Conservative voter and donor who once considered standing for mayor of London, he could call on politicians as distinguished as Margaret Thatcher to support charity events at his clubs.And Baroness Thatcher was not the only unpredictable convert to is undeniable charm.Others included Princess Diana, Sir Bruce Forsyth, Diana Dors and Professor Stephen Hawking, of whom more later.At his height Stringfellow had clubs in New York, Miami, LA, Paris and Dublin, as well as London, an apartment overlooking the Thames, a villa in Majorca and was wealthy enough to charter a private jet on at least one occasion to fly his chihuahuas to Italy.Alan DavidsonSilverhubREXShutterstockThe legendary lap-dancing magnate died yesterday at the age of 77 after a battle with cancerOh and then there&rsquos the little matter of the 2,000 women he claimed to have bedded.Yesterday the tributes were flooding in from his celebrity friends.&ldquoA terrific guy who lived life to the full, was radio DJ Tony Blackburn&rsquos verdict.&ldquoRIP Peter Stringfellow, tweeted Boy George.&ldquoWow, a big part of our lives and one of Sheffield&rsquos finest. What a character. He introduced me and my mum to Princess Diana.Meanwhile the actress Su Pollard praised his business acumen: &ldquoHe was a fantastic role model for other entrepreneurs. I liked him because he was always warm, he could have probably been in showbiz in another area but he chose to be an entrepreneur.It all amounts to quite a journey for a steelworker&rsquos son from Sheffield.Never one for booklearning, he left school at 15 and the man described by one obituarist as &ldquoBritain&rsquos greatest sex salesman was rather more innocent in those days.Peter Stringfellow has died of cancer aged 77. See his life in pictures.1 of 21Queues snaked down the street.Celebrities and high rollers couldn&rsquot get enough of it.And paparazzi and gossip columnists watched their every move &ndash often tipped off by Stringfellow himself.John Travolta strutted his stuff on the dance floor.The DJ Kenny Everett was photographed with his face buried in a woman&rsquos breasts.And soul singer Stevie Wonder once performed a set that went on till 5am.Which brings us back to Professor Hawking, who was invited to dinner in 2003.&ldquoI asked him if he wanted to discuss the galaxy, said Stringfellow.&ldquoHe types into his little box and out comes that synthesised voice: &lsquoNo. I want girls. Ha ha ha! I WANT GIRLS!&rsquoBY THIS time the club owner had persuaded Westminster Council&rsquos licensing chiefs to withdraw the stipulation that all table-side dancers must wear at least a G-string.REXShutterstockHe had an eventful love life that saw him marry three timesFour years later he opened another club in Soho called Angels.But times changed.Suddenly fewer and fewer people were buying the idea that his clubs were about &ldquothe respectful appreciation of female beauty.His celebrity friends, swept away by a wave of political correctness, no longer wanted to be photographed at his clubs.At the end it was more about self-made men, footballers and the odd actor who didn&rsquot give a damn, such as Charlie Sheen or Jack Nicholson.In his final years, much of the public interest in Stringfellow was focused on his personal life.He had an eventful love life that saw him marry three times.Wife number one was Norma Williams, the first girl he met after he left school.They had a daughter named Karen but Stringfellow walked out when she was about two-and-a-half years old.His second marriage to Coral Wright produced a son, Scott, and lasted 24 years but Stringfellow admits he was by no means faithful.He once said: &ldquoMy business came first and along with that came the opportunity to have other women, and I took full advantage.The woman who finally tamed him was, improbably enough, a convent-educated ballet dancer 42 years his junior called Bella Wright.&ldquoShe popped in after doing The Nutcracker, he said.&ldquoI sent champagne over to her group and, when she came over afterwards, I got my driver to take her home. It went from there.TWITTERProfessor Hawking, was invited to dinner in 2003In 2008 he was diagnosed with lung cancer and had half his left lung removed.The operation was a success and he and Bella were married in Barbados on Valentine&rsquos Day 2009.They had their first child Rosabella four years later.She was followed by Angelo in 2015.&ldquoThere will come a time when I&rsquom not going to be around but they will have support from each other and my wife, he told me in 2015.&ldquoShe&rsquos a young woman and she will still be young when they are teenagers.&ldquoSo they&rsquoll have wonderful support from their mother and various other parts of the family. And their memory of me, a doting father. I think in this day and age that is a lot to leave your children with.

title: UK weather Met Office forecast sweltering heat from Africa to engulf the nation weekend
story: Getty &bull Met OfficeCoral has put odds on June bringing whopping temperatures of 30CWarm air from &ldquoAfrica and the Continent is pushing towards Britain, bringing figures of up to 24C in southern parts of the UK but will continue to bring a risk of thunderstorms, according to Met Office spokeswoman Nicola Maxey.She said: &ldquoWe have warm air coming up from Africa and the Continent and this will bring the risk of thunderstorms primarily in the southeast during the rest of the week.&ldquoBy the weekend we expect temperatures widely around 23C or 24C and there is a chance we could see 27C in the southeast.&ldquoThe east coast may be fresher as sea temperatures are slightly cooler at the moment, however elsewhere it will be warm and humid.                BBC weather forecaster quizzed by Simon McCoy over forecast                BBC Weather: 'Sharp showers' to hit UK despite high temperaturesThe boiling forecast from the weather body comes as bookmaker Coral has put odds on June bringing whopping temperatures of 30C.The company&rsquos Harry Aitkenhead said: &ldquoThe summer of 2018 is only just beginning and our odds reflect the view that we&rsquore expecting some very warm weather to come this June, mostly towards the back end of the month.&ldquoIt&rsquos not beyond the realms of possibility that we see the hottest June day of all time, as we&rsquove already seen the hottest April day for 69 years this year and records are tumbling all around.Friday will start off grey and with showers in northern areas of the UK.Glorious Britain basks in bank holiday sunshine.                    PA1 of 34People take part in a game of beach volleyball on Boscombe beach in DorsetHowever these will be few and far between with the majority of Britons seeing soaring temperatures.Met Office meteorologist Alex Deakin commented: &ldquoIt could be a bit of a grey start to Friday, maybe one or two showers over northern England and Wales but they will fade away.For most it is a dry morning commute.&ldquoAs we run through the day we won&rsquot see a great deal of change but there is the potential for some thundery showers to break out once more over western Scotland, possibly Northern Ireland.&ldquoLate in the day, maybe across some parts of Devon and Cornwall there could be some showers too.&ldquoBut for most on Friday it is dry and it&rsquos fine.Eastern coasts will be cooler thanks to an increased presence of cloud and a cool breeze, but the rest of the nation could see highs of 24C.Mr Deakin went on: &ldquoThe east coast will again see cloud and with a breeze from the sea there will be cooler temperatures.&ldquoElsewhere temperatures will really respond to the strong June sunshine, high teens, low twenties.Thousands of bolts of lightning lit up Britain last night in a spectacular thunderstorm.                     Jan Sedlacek  SWNS1 of 13Bolts of lightning illuminate the skies over Worcestershire &ldquoWe might get to 23 or 24C in one or two places.&ldquoIt will be a very pleasant Friday evening if you&rsquove got plans for the outdoors but again one or two heavy and thundery showers will occur in western parts of Scotland and the odd shower for Northern Ireland, maybe south-west England.But they should fade through the evening.Scotland and Northern Ireland will be plagued by thunderstorms on Saturday while the rest of the UK is set for another beautiful summer's day.Similar temperatures are expected for Saturday as sweltering sunshine covers the country.Mr Deakin went on: &ldquoTemperatures will hold up later on, making for another mild and humid night, so it will not be a cold start to the weekend.Met OfficeThe nation could see highs of 24C over the weekend&ldquoAgain on Saturday we need to watch out for big thunderstorms across western Scotland, very hit or miss but they could drop a lot of rain and they could be quite slow moving too.&ldquoNorthern Ireland will also be at risk for a potential downpour whereas further south there is the risk of a heavy shower but it will be very isolated.&ldquoMost places will be dry and fine and warm in the sunshine, again parts of the east coast could be quite cloudy and again the coasts will be fresher, more comfortable and less humid.Met OfficeScotland and Northern Ireland will be plagued by thunderstorms on SaturdayBut inland the low twenties will be reached easily, mid-twenties are possible in some spots.&ldquoFor most it is warm sunshine for much of this weekend.Do watch out though, there will be some downpours in places and the coasts will once again be on the cool side.

title: Hurricane Aletta 2018 tropical storm path maps Mexico
story: Tropical storm Aletta developed into a hurricane on Thursday afternoon.Aletta is currently 450 miles off the coast of Mexico and not expected to be a threat to land.Experts predict it to remain a hurricane during the weekend before being downgraded to a tropical storm on Sunday.The National Hurricane Centre predicted wind speeds of the hurricane could peak at 120mph.A second named storm could develop over the weekend following an area of low pressure.Look through this gallery to see the predicted wind speeds of Hurricane Aletta from the National Hurricane Center.You will also see the estimated arrival times and a forecast cone predicting the path of the storm.National Hurricane Centre&bullWeather ChannelHurricane Aletta path maps: Category 3 hurricane forms near Mexico&nbsp

title: Brexit news EU ends British military in Europe over security issues
story: EU and UK advisers are discussing foreign policy co-operation in talks this week but the warning that British secondments will end after Brexit seemingly makes Brussels line clear.At present 14 British personnel are seconded to Brussels - 13 serve as EU military staff while one is working in the crisis management and planning directorate of the European External Action Service.Britain has similar arrangements with the USA and officials argue it is in the interests of European security that the system is maintained post-Brexit.The Ministry of Defence said British secondments will now be considered by the European Commission on a case-by-case basis &ndash but the current fierce row over the Galileo satellite program which German wants Britain axed from for security reasons does not bode well. At present 14 British personnel are seconded to Brussels                EU WARNING: Merkel told to spend MORE in eurozone                Jeremy Corbyn winning Brexit exchanges with Theresa May spells TROUBLE Military veterans parade during the annual Remembrance Sunday Service at the CenotaphSir Stuart Peach, Chief of the UK defence staffThe department added that there were &ldquochallenges surrounding new applications and extensions of secondments post Brexit.A senior EU official indicated that the idea of British officials being seconded onto EU bodies would require major political upheaval and rule changes and as such was a non-starter.Earlier this week Air Chief Marshal Sir Stuart Peach, the chief of the UK defence staff, urged negotiators to find some common ground over another hotly-contested military project the European Defence Fund.He said: &ldquoAt times like this the military to military relationships matter more than ever.&ldquoThe history and geography of our nation doesn&rsquot change because of Brexit. We have to find ways of working together with our European friends and partners. We have to find a way to keep the door open as structures evolve for third party access.

title: iphone smartphone listen to what you say target adverts facebook instagram twitter
story: A security expert has warned your phone regularly listens to what you sayA researcher has warned third-party apps such as Facebook, Instagram and Twitter can access data about your personal conversations.It is unknown what triggers the technology, but one researcher has claimed the technique is 100 percent legal and is even covered in your mobile apps user agreements.Most modern smartphones use AI assistants, which are triggered by spoken command words and phrases such as &ldquoHey Siri and &ldquoOk Google and this can be accessed by third-party apps when the right permissions are enabled.Dr Peter Henway, a senior security consultant for cybersecurity firm Asterisk, said: &ldquoFrom time to time, snippets of audio do go back to apps like Facebook's servers but there's no official understanding what the triggers for that are.                iOS 12 update: Beta download could reveal Apple has THIS new product                Face the future with these space-age beauty gadgets&ldquoWhether it's timing or location-based or usage of certain functions, apps are certainly pulling those microphone permissions and using those periodically.&ldquoAll the internals of the applications send this data in encrypted form, so it's very difficult to define the exact trigger.This means that when you talk about a niche product or dream holiday, apps can place adverts on your timeline with related products and services.Dr Henway said tech giants such as Facebook could use thousands of triggers to mine your conversations for advertising purposes.FROM Facebook to WhatsApp - these apps are the worst for eating through your monthly data allowance                    EXPRESS NEWSPAPERS1 of 9Worst apps for draining your dataHe added: &ldquoSeeing as Google are open about it, I would personally assume the other companies are doing the same.&ldquoReally, there's no reason they wouldn't be.&ldquoIt makes good sense from a marketing standpoint and their end-user agreements and the law both allow it, so I would assume they're doing it, but there's no way to be sure.Companies are now using increasingly sophisticated technology to mine your activity on websites and apps to create personalised adverts.Third-party apps such as Facebook and Instagram can access data about your personal conversationsElectronic markers, known as cookies, are used by websites to gather information on users' online activity, which is then passed on to advertisers for personalised digital advertisement.The practice is not illegal, however, under the 1998 Data Protection Act, a person must actively agree to their data being collected and used for advertisements.Facebook denies it uses smartphone microphones to gather information for the purposes of targeted advertising.A number of other companies, including WhatsApp, also deny bugging private conversations, describing any evidence as a pure coincidence.When you talk about a niche product or dream holiday apps can place adverts on your timeline However, experts agree that technology to listen to millions of conversations for repeated phrases could exist.Companies have developed algorithms that can find patterns and pick-out potentially useful things about behaviour and interests.

title: theresa may customs brexit deal
story: If rebel Remainers defeat their own Government over the crucial EU Withdrawal Bill they could destroy our negotiating position and commit us to staying in a customs union — a life sentence of taking orders from Brussels.Mrs May’s compromises and indecision are already damaging her . . . and that’s among her donors and the party faithful. Imagine how fast Tory fortunes, shored up by Leave voters, will nose-dive if Brexit is fatally wounded.Remainers already blame them for holding the referendum. Leavers will blame them for negating 17.4million votes.There is only one solution. Tory Remainers must put aside their personal views and respect the manifesto promises they stood on last year.When Home Secretary Sajid Javid says it will cost lives, he’s not exaggerating. He’s pointing out the reality of Brussels turning its back on the peerless UK ­security services it relies so heavily on.EU bureaucrats plainly consider a few more terrorist victims mere collateral damage in their zeal to punish us.This is the truth behind the “happy, inclusive” EU of Remainer fantasies.It is a hard-nosed trading cabal, run mafia-style by unelected bullies treating voters as cannon fodder.IT would be an act of national self-harm for MPs to reject a third Heathrow runway.Transport Secretary Chris Grayling is poised to give it the nod, possibly today. The Commons must back it this month.Aside from the huge boost to the economy, it is crucial to improve our global transport links for the post-Brexit era.But The Sun has long supported expanding Heathrow AND Gatwick.This new runway will be at capacity almost as soon as it is finally finished.So much for our country becoming nasty and intolerant!We warmly congratulate “Lost Voice Guy” Lee Ridley — and Simon Cowell.A belting series, with a wonderful winner.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hereditary actor alex wolff claims filming the movie was so scary it gave him ptsd
story: Alex Wolff, who plays the teenage son of Toni Collette and Gabriel Byrnes characters in the film, said he was in a raw and volatile state during shooting.The chilling horror stars Desperate Housewives Colette and follows the nightmarish goings on to her family following the death of her mum Ellen.It was released to rave reviews at the Sundance Film Festival, with some shocked critics describing it as the most terrifying theyd ever seen.Wolff told Vice: It stuck with me while we were filming, and it stuck with me well after.When I started talking about it, all these flashes with all this disturbing s**t I went through sorta came back in a flood.It’s hard to describe eloquently, it’s just a feeling. I don’t think you can go through something like this and not have some sort of PTSD afterwards.The two-minute trailer for the frightfest was released in January and is backed by an eerie staccato soundtrack and builds from Ellens funeral through to the violent effects of the evil hanging over the family.Tonis character Annie appears to be a target for whatever supernatural force is at play when her daughter Charlie (Milly Shapiro) asks: Whos going to look after me when you die?IMDB says of the plot: The more they discover, the more they find themselves trying to outrun the sinister fate they seem to have inherited.With Hereditary being compared to horror classic The Exorcist, it is likely to have fans quaking in their seats when it hits cinemas in June.

title: florida lake nona boy plays inflatable alligator garden
story: The terrifying video was recorded by Nicole Mojica while her son, Timmy, played on a slip and slide at their home in Orlando, Florida.Mojica told WFTV she always performs gator checks in her backyard before letting her kids play outside.She said: I saw the brown chair move. Oh my God.Never would I expect one so close to us. They say they are afraid. Well, he wasnt.And he went down the slip and slide and into the pond.At first glance, the alligator is extremely hard to spot.But upon closer inspection, you can see the reptile lurking just next to a chair Timmy is standing beside.It was only later she discovered how close the alligator had come to her son.In the video commentary, she states: Summer fun, another day. Go, Timmy, go.She then even jokes about gator wrangling.Wrangling gators. I was hoping to make one of those funny YouTube videos - like the gator did something to you and you popped up in the air.Donny Aldarelli, an alligator expert, said mating season is followed by nesting season which is when residents can normally find them roaming around their properties.

title: france landlord revenge nightmare tenants rubbish new home
story: Astonishing footage shows the moment Thomas Ravaux, from Rozoy-sur-Serre, Aisne, dumped a truck full of rubbish on the familys doorstep.Thomas last week posted photos of the mess the tenants left on his Facebook page, saying: Shame on you.He wrote: This is how this flat was returned to me.Living like that with three kids, bravo. Shame on you.Good luck to your new landlord.The post attracted 2,500 views and showed rooms piled high with abandoned furniture, clutter, rubbish and junk.But he hatched a plan, and last Friday uploaded the remarkable video showing him handing it all back to them.He captioned the video: Return to sender.Thomas told LUnion the family had left the property without any notice a year ago and failed to return their keys or give him the opportunity to do an inventory check.The clip has now gone viral and has been shared almost 300,000 times.

title: kenya poacher crews elephants lions rhinos savannah
story: Illegal hunting has put the lives of lions, elephants, zebras and leopards at risk as they face constant danger from trophy hunters and poachers.The candid images have been captured by British photographer Gary Roberts in his new book ‘Voices from the Savannah’.The book aims to highlight the horrors inflicted on the majestic creatures as well as the dangers faced by the anti-poaching patrol as they try to protect the animals from money-hungry hunters.The snapper’s eye-opening collection, compiled from his extensive work in Tanzania and Kenya, has been applauded by Sir David Attenborough and primatologist Jane Goodall.Images within the book included a lioness with severe damage to her neck after being held in a tight metal snare, as well as an elephant’s foot which became infected after being caught in a poacher’s trap.Roberts work brought him into contact with conservationists and experts in the region, who painted a bleak future for the dwindling wildlife of Africa.He has now urged the public to back his campaign and help spread his book as far and wide as possible.The 52-year-old said: “I’m aiming to get as many people to see these images as possible, to see what is happening to our world’s wildlife.“If people can get behind this campaign, then we can spread it far and wide and that’s what needs to happen to help these animals.”The snapper added that when he first visited Africa three decades ago, the number of wild lions was at 200,000 but now it is 20,000 – a staggering 90 per cent decline.He claims that if the practice continues, these majestic creatures will be unlikely to survive the next 10 to 15 years.More than 33,000 elephants are poached each year, or one every 20 minutes, with even smaller numbers of surviving black rhinos and leopards.Roberts said: “As you can see from the pictures, its a pretty desperate situation.“One of the really poignant moments was seeing a lion which had been snared which I came across in the middle of the bush.“Thats a symbol of what is happening in general.“The demand for the poaching trade is from outside Africa, in the Far East and also the US.“The anti-poaching team face such a dangerous job every day as the poachers will do anything - even risk their lives - to get a rhinos horn or elephant tusk.“The death rate per capita for anti-poachers is higher than a soldier in combat in Iraq.”The demand for ivory - sometimes referred to as ‘white-gold’ – remains the highest from China where it is used in decorative items, while rhino horns are highly sought after across parts of Asia for use in traditional medicines.Crocodiles are also prime targets for poachers for their skin, which is turned into leather and used in the high-end fashion industry.

title: pensioner driving mobility scooter wales dual carriageway traffic
story: Im allowed on, the man yelled as a long line of cars formed behind him on the A48, a notoriously busy road in Newport, Wales.Wearing sunglasses and pink shorts, he appears to be in no hurry at all as he traverses a busy roundabout with honks from angry drivers echoing around him.Cars can be seen slowly trudging along behind him as he takes the exit towards a dual carriageway, Wales Online reported.Here, the man filming the video stops alongside him and says: Mate, youre not allowed to drive them on there.I dont think youre allowed to ride that on the road. You could cause an accident!Other motorists were less polite: Many are heard beeping their horns and yelling: Get off the road!The elderly man responds by saying hes allowed to drive the vehicle on the road.Witness Wesley Kenny told Wales Online: I stopped and tried to encourage him not to go on the duals - but he said the DVLA had allowed him to.Only class 3 invalid carriages are allowed on the roads and even then, they are not permitted on motorways and driving on dual carriageways is discouraged, government rules state.It is unclear if the man was driving this class of vehicle, which has to weigh less than 150kg, have a maximum speed of 8mph  and front and rear lights and reflectors.A scooter must also have a rear view mirror and efficient breaking system to qualify.

title: thousands of brits set to get more cash as they move on to universal credit after rules change
story: Ministers have admitted that too many people are losing money when they switch to the new benefits regime.So they have softened the rules - meaning claimants will get more support to ensure they dont lose out.Those affected by the rule tweak will include working parents, the disabled and jobseekers who find work but lose it again.Its likely to mean thousands of Brits getting hundreds more pounds a year in benefits.And many more who lost out will get money back too.The Government has introduced a scheme called transitional protection which ensures that claimants who are moved to Universal Credit dont see a reduction in their overall level of handouts if their circumstances are unchanged.If their UC entitlement is less than they previously got, they are eligible for a cash top-up.Today Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey announced transitional protection would be extended more widely.Seriously disabled adults who live alone but rely on care, currently getting Severe Disability Premium, will now be guaranteed extra money when they start on UC.Parents who are in work will also get transitional protection which ensures they wont be stung if their cost of childcare goes up.And anyone who sees their earnings increase, for example because they start a new job, only for their pay to fall again shortly afterwards will see their benefits ring-fenced.Campaigners said that some families were £147 worse off per month.At least 4,000 people are set to benefit from the backpayments because they lost out when the moved from severe disabilities benefits onto Universal Credit. And more people who lost out when they moved into temporary work will also receive a boost.Ms McVey said: This Government is committed to delivering a welfare system that supports claimants and is fair to taxpayers.Universal Credit is currently being rolled out across the country but has been hit by a string of delays and blunders.

title: foreign office minister says government could hold a referendum on the brexit deal
story: Speaking in Berlin, Boris Johnson’s deputy said Brits could be asked whether or not they like Theresa May’s agreement on a future relationship with Brussels – or would prefer a No Deal.He firmly ruled out the idea of a second referendum – saying it would be “significantly more divisive than the first” and cause lasting distrust.But he said: “It would, I suppose be possible to ask the people in a referendum if they liked the exit deal or not, but that would mean the choice would be between the exit deal on offer or no deal at all.“It would not in reality offer people the option of reversing the original decision to leave the EU.”Pro-EU campaigners leapt on the comments to say “the floodgates are now well and truly open” and the public should have a choice.Labour MP Chuka Umunna said: “Alan Duncan is absolutely right to back the idea of a People’s Vote on the final Brexit deal.“As a Foreign Office minister, and deputy to Boris Johnson, he must know as well as anybody what an utter shambles Brexit has become.”Best for Britain said: “Though Alan Duncan has tried to shut the door on that vote giving people the option to remain, the floodgates are now well and truly open.The public don’t want or deserve a false choice, gamed by the government. They want a real say.”Theresa May last December said a second referendum would be a “betrayal”. It came after Labour deputy leader Tom Watson said “you shouldn’t rule anything out”.Mrs May said: “The best way to get the worst deal would be to suggest that we agree to a second referendum, but it’s more than that.“It would actually be betraying the British people. This Parliament gave them the vote and it is up to us to deliver on the result of that vote.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: baby born without mother birth certificate trans dad
story: The tot is the child of a single parent who was born a woman, but who now lives as a man.He was able to naturally conceive, but legally became a man when the child was born after having surgery.The man, unable to be named, wants to be identified as the childs father or parent on its birth certificate.But the High Court in London heard a birth registrar told the dad people who give birth to their children must be registered as mums.Now the parent is fighting to be recognised as a father, and says forcing him to register as the childs mother breaches his human right to respect for private and family life.He argues the interference and discrimination by The Registrar General for England and Wales is not proportionate or necessary in the light of changes which have evolved in society.Appearing in front of Mr Justice Francis today the man held his child as he sat next to a lawyer.He stood to rock the baby to sleep as legal arguments from both sides were heard at the High Court in London.This can be done at the local register office for where the baby was born, or at the hospital.If parents are unable to register the birth in the area the baby was born, another office can send the details to the correct office.Usually parents need to provide their names, the place and date of the birth, name, surname and sex of the baby, places and dates of parents birth, dates of parents marriage or civil partnership, parents jobs and the mothers maiden name.The parent registering the birth needs to take a form of ID. The judge said if the man won his fight ministers might have to consider changing the law.A decision is due in the historic case after a trial in September.Lawyers say other transgender men have given birth but have been registered on birth certificates as mothers.Earlier this week we reported how a therapist is raising her three-year-old son as gender neutral.She told has told how he is as happy wearing a tutu and glittery shoes as he is playing with a toy truck.Tired of “sexist stereotypes”, Kristin Hambridge, 32, from Boston, Massachusetts, is letting Jackson decide for himself which gender he identifies as.

title: midges wreak havoc across scotland as walkers film themselves covered in savage insects
story: Scottish locals have even claimed to be trapped in their own homes as the insects descend with a vengeance.Scott Sweeney, from Argyll, who works outdoors as a deer manager, says midges have “exploded” this week.The 31-year-old shared a video clip of hundreds of tiny midges clinging to his hands and buzzing around him as he sat on a hill with his dog, Leah.He said: “They are always bad, but I don’t think I have ever seen this before in my life. They may well calm off, but at this exact moment, they are the worst ever.”The unusually cold start to the year has meant the insects have arrived a little later than normal, but Scottish locals have said they are now being terrorised.Meanwhile, Lucy Fraser, from Rowardennan, Stirling, says she has become a prisoner in her own home.The hotelier claims a contractor even had to stop laying new decking at her home because the midges are so bad.She said: “I insist the guests don’t open the windows. If they do it’s horrific and believe me some do and regret it.“Each year from the end of May to October I become a prisoner and wouldnt dare go out the door before 10am and after 5pm.“I’ve been here 22 years and it gets worse every year.Social media users have also been quick to share their shock at the state of the midges already.Lynn Bindon said: “A zombie apocalypse has nothing on Scotlands midge season.Stay safe people.”Fiona Macdonald Fraser added: “Ughhh! Gives me the fear.”Sue Wright commented: “I was in Lochgilphead for work last weekend. I literally walked from the car to the hospital and was eaten alive. Still suffering.”And Audrey Hutchison said simply: “Little s***s.”Midges typically begin to emerge during the end of May before the female biting midges arrive in June to officially kick off the season.In 2017 a record number of 68 million midges descended on Scotland - a 40 per cent rise on the year before - but experts have not revealed this years’ estimated figures.Dr Alison Blackwell, from the Scottish Midge Forecast, said: “This year has seen a late start to the midge season. However this week we have seen very high levels of midges.“This is usually reflected in the the amount of insect repellent we sell. It’s been slow the previous weeks but this week we have seen very high sales. We have had lots of people calling.“It seems particularly in Wales, Ireland, and the Highlands of Scotland where it appears to be the worst at this time of year and where we are getting most calls from.“It is likely to keep up like this for a few weeks as long as the warm and wet weather lasts.”

title: michael gove double uk blue belt
story: The Environment Secretary unveils another 41 new Marine Conservation Zones, adding to the 50 that already exist.Any new human activity is banned in zones, from coastline buildings and dredging to offshore wind farms and rigs.And current projects will be reduced or ended, to allow destroyed sea life and beds to regenerate again.The new zones will cover 12,000 square kilometres of marine habitats, an area almost eight times the size of Greater London.They span from spanning Devon in the south west to Holderness on the Yorkshire coast.The announcement comes on World Oceans Day, and is made to coincide with the G7 summit of world leaders gathering in Quebec.Theresa May will champion the new size of the UK’s blue belt in talks with the leaders of the world’s seven richest Western nations on how to protect the oceans.The PM will also urge them to follow Britain’s groundbreaking lead to slash the use of throwaway plastics such as coffee cups, straws, bags and stirrers.Mrs May will tell US president Donald Trump and others: Marine plastics pollution is one of the greatest environmental challenges facing the world today.“Today marks an important step towards completing our Blue Belt.“We are creating safe havens for our cherished wildlife and putting the UK at the forefront of marine protection.”There is an urgent need for greater global action and co-ordination on marine plastics pollution.“This is a global problem, requiring global solutions.”The new action – which Mr Gove will today begin a consultation on - will see two fifths of the UK coast protected, by either zones or other specially designated areas.Mr Gove, added: “The UK is surrounded by some of the richest and most diverse sea life in the world. We must protect these precious habitats for future generations. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mays brexit bodge 2021
story: As Brexit Secretary David Davis threatened to quit, the PM agreed to a “time-limited” plan where the UK would mirror EU customs rules after Brexit.But senior Government insiders admitted the new “cut-off” date was meaningless and unenforceable.And No 10 conceded Britain may be left on the hook for billions more in fees to the EU.Livid Tories demanded the PM press ahead with preparations for a “No Deal” Brexit given the deadlock over trade talks with Brussels.And former UKIP leader Nigel Farage said: “It is now time for all Brexiteers to resist.“This is clearly a recipe for keeping the UK inside the EU’s Customs Union and is completely unacceptable to all people who voted to leave the EU.”Meanwhile, as the Government descended into farce,It’s Alice in Wonderland stuff.”Britain is due to leave a post-Brexit transition phase at the end of 2020.The bitter row centred on a “backstop” plan with the EU that would take effect if a new customs system was not in place by then.Mrs May had insisted on a text that said the UK would mirror all current Brussels rules on customs indefinitely.Last night she refused to guarantee the backstop option will end by the date agreed with Mr Davis. She said: “The backstop is time limited. It may never be used.”In a letter to Tories, seen by The Times, even the PM called the UK proposal “unpalatable but at worst temporary” and “in no way the Government’s intended or desired” result.1000: Mrs May summons Liam Fox and Boris Johnson to test their views. The Brexiteers warn her she is risking a major upset if she does not back down.1030: Convinced Brexit ministers are on the verge of a mass walkout, No10 agrees to amend the backstop proposals to include a desire to end it by 2021 but in vague terms.1045: Mrs May sends her lieutenant Robbie Gibb to the Brexit department to hammer out a fudge.1100: Mrs May enrages David Davis by briefing journalists that a deal has already been done.1130: PM presents fudged words to David Davis who signs them off, averting his resignation. DD publishes statement declaring victory.1230: Theresa May’s war cabinet meet.1600: She flies to Canada, with aides spinning that she had pulled a fast one.PM Theresa May refused to give any guarantee that the backstop will end by the date she agreed with David Davis as her best expectation.Her defiant stand risks alarming Brexiteer Tory MPs afresh that Britain will be tied to EU customs rules for years to come.She was pressed twice on the way to the G7 summit in Canada for a guarantee that the backstop won’t last any longer than a year.But Mrs May would only say: “I have always been clear that the point about the back stop is it’s time limited, and it may never be used.“It only comes in if for technical reasons the agreed end state customs arrangement has not been possible to bring into place by 1st of January 2021.“As we’ve said today, we expect that end state customs arrangement at the latest will be in by December 2021, and we’ll be working to make sure it’s in earlier than that.”Mrs May also denied that Brexiteer Cabinet ministers Boris Johnson and Liam Fox were livid with her for trying to railroad the backstop decision through without a specifically stated time limit.Quizzed on if she had tried to deceive them, the PM hit back: “No. We’ve agreed previously the nature and structure of the backstop”.A senior Government source said Mr Davis had been “bambooz­led”. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit boosts support scot tories
story: Top pollster Sir John Curtice found the SNP’s pro-EU stance alienated its own voters in last year’s General Election, helping the Scottish Tories secure their astonishing 12 seats.Analysis showed support for the SNP fell significantly among eurosceptics from 51 per cent to 36 per cent in the 2017 election.But support north of the border for the Scottish Tories among eurosceptics doubled to 28 per cent.The National Centre for Social Research chapter from this year’s British Social Attitudes survey found 40 per cent of Scots are Europhiles but a far higher 58 per cent are eurosceptics.Sir John said: “Nicola Sturgeon  anticipated that Brexit would increase support for independence. Instead, Brexit has made both independence and the SNP relatively less popular among those Scots who are not very enthusiastic about the EU, even if they did vote to Remain.“So far this has been a tendency to presume that the fall in SNP support in the 2017 election simply represented a rejection of the party’s plans for a second independence referendum.“Our research suggests that it was also occasioned by a dislike of its pro-EU stance among some of former SNP voters.He added: “Meanwhile, far from simply winning votes as a result of her opposition to a second independence referendum, Ruth Davidson appears to have profited from a swing among Leave voters.“That leaves Ms Davidson with an electorate whose views on Europe are in many cases strikingly different from her own.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dog thief cruella de vil king charles spaniels
story: Bridget Darling, 40 — who has two-tone hair and wears a fur coat like the 101 Dalmatians villain — was nabbed with 11 King Charles spaniels in her three-bed semi.She and husband Barry, 51, were also involved in the theft of at least four more pooches — in cahoots with Barbara Petrie-Harrison, 45, and her lover Craig Jackson, 42.Petrie-Harrison had bought a spaniel from breeder Madeline Cowling but later broke into her property in Market Rasen, Lincs, with Jackson to steal 15 dogs worth £6,500.The spaniels — one of which was pregnant — were then passed on to Barry Darling in Birstall, West Yorks.But cops were able to connect a car seen on CCTV in the area — a black Vauxhall Astra — to the Darlings.The investigation following the theft in September 2015 led to the arrest of all four.Judge Andrew Easteal ridiculed the defendants at Lincoln crown court, saying: “Let’s be clear, this was as deplorable and awful as it was amateurish and doomed to fail.“The speed it was detected and identified was almost embarrassingly fast.”Both Darlings admitted handling stolen property. Petrie-Harrison and Jackson, of Basingstoke, admitted burglary.They all got suspended prison sentences of between 12 and 16 months.But despite the convictions, the dogs could not be returned to their owner because they did not have microchips.Ms Cowling said: “This is two years later and I am still very anxious. I just wish they could tell me where my babies are.“Even though they were kennelled, they were very much loved. I just want my dogs back.”Earlier this year, analysis of crime stats by an insurance firm put Lincolnshire as the dog theft capital of Britain.Another breeder from the county said: “People watch 101 Dalmatians and Cruella de Vil and think it is only a movie, but this is happening in real life.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits should stop sympathising with broken heroes
story: Critics frequently claim Iraq and Afghanistan have blighted a generation of personnel.But in his last interview as Chief of the Defence Staff, Sir Stuart Peach insisted the armchair generals were out of touch and ex-Forces staff were full of fight.He said: “We are not all heroes and we are not all broken.“The absolute majority of people who served in the Armed Forces return to fulfilling lives enriched by the experience.“When we break people, which unfortunately military service does because of the nature of it, we put them back together. The rehab element is simply the best.“Of course we would wish, and hope for, fewer wounded servicemen, but we do look after them.“We’ve listened to mental health concerns and provided a lot of extra money, programmes, places.” But he demanded urgent action over the plight of Troubles veterans facing legal action.He said: “The further back you go to tactical events 50, 60, 70 years ago, the less likely you are to end up with an outcome any way.”Sir Stuart, 62, also insisted conventional forces must evolve to deal with all future threats.He said: “We need to move off a narrative derived from Dad’s Army and nostalgia. We have to move on with equipment, new missions and capabilities.” He becomes Nato’s top commander next week as chairman of its military committee. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit sell out david davis sun says
story: The Government intends to offer the EU a “backstop” arrangement that could shackle us to its restrictive ­customs rules for ever to resolve the over-hyped Irish border issue.Brexit Secretary David Davis managed to get an end-date inserted, December 2021, but it was fudged as a mere “expectation”. It is not legally binding.It is supposedly temporary. But that is naïve. It gives the EU no incentive to negotiate the free trade deal we want.They will have us where they want us. They can reject Irish solutions for ever.We would be stuck,  unwillingly locked into their customs rules — but now with no say over them.No meaningful external trade deals. No full independence. Brexit’s key  economic argument destroyed. Without having prepared the country to walk away with “no deal”, what could we do?No wonder Remainers are cock-a-hoop.Is there embarrassment in No10? Or fear? No. Just GLEE, that Theresa May had stitched up Davis with the wooliness of the wording. “She’s done him like a kipper again,” said one source.It’s not the Brexit Secretary done up like a kipper. It’s Brexit and 17.4million voters. Mrs May must stand up for them. All we see is capitulation.AMAZON is creating 2,500 jobs. Fantastic — except House of Fraser is cutting 6,000. And 5,300 could go at Poundworld.Look no further for an illustration of the carnage on our high streets and the main reason why.Our stores simply cannot cope  with the cheap online competition alongside the sky-high business rates  on their premises.Before long our towns may only house restaurants, coffee shops, nail bars, barbers and tattooists. To retain a vibrant mix, stores need a level playing field.Which means far lower taxes for them. And Amazon paying every penny they owe.THE Tories need to stop swallowing the line that taxes must rise to fund the NHS.The sole reason the public seems prepared to pay more, as a poll indicates, is that both the Tories and Labour have convinced them it’s the only solution.It isn’t. Tax hikes should be a last resort. Government waste is still vast. So is the insane aid budget. Cut those first.The Tories cannot win votes posing as a saner version of Corbyn’s Labour. They should be unshakeable defenders of low taxes to boost the economy.Raising the overall burden beyond its  30-year high is political suicide, no matter the cause.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: parental advice alarm clocks sleeping tips
story: Prof Adam Joinson said teenagers lack the cognitive skills to realise that staying up all night using their mobile would mean being tired at school the next day.And he said those who rely on their phone’s alarm to wake should instead use a traditional one.Prof Joinson said he and his 17-year-old son had endless fights about the lad’s device being in his room at night — and he had banned its use there until he is 18.He told a Cheltenham Science Festival event: “Parents should take the phones off their kids at night. Store the charger downstairs and buy cheap alarm clocks.“Young people do not have the ability until they are in their 20s to fully understand consequences tomorrow of actions now.“This is a basic developmental thing and cognitively they cannot do it.“As parents we have a responsibility of care.Parents are remiss if they allow their kids to keep phones in their bedrooms.”The University of Bath academic also said those who rely on smartphone technology had “effectively outsourced their analytic thinking to Google or Siri or to Alexa”. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: paedo bishop peter ball cover up claims
story: But the support Prince Charles is said to have given a senior bishop while he defended himself against allegations of sex abuse is now putting the judgment of our future king in serious question.The prince let Peter Ball rent a Duchy of Cornwall home following an early caution for gross indecency against a 16-year-old trainee monk, and is said to have sent letters of support to him while he was under investigation.So close was the disgraced former Bishop of Gloucester to Charles that they prayed together in Highgrove and he was a guest at the prince’s wedding to Camilla Parker Bowles in 2005.Now an independent inquiry is examining whether Ball, 86, exploited his powerful friends — and if this was at the heart of a cover-up that allowed him to evade justice for so long. His first arrest was in 1992 but it took another 23 years before his victims were taken seriously.Aides of Charles said this week that the royal is prepared to send a witness statement to the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse (IICSA), answering whatever questions it has. Ball, lauded for his work alongside vulnerable youths, was also close to then Archbishop of Canterbury George Carey.Last year, a report found that Lord Carey, now 82, and other senior Church of England figures “colluded” with Ball to prevent him facing criminal charges and failed to protect his victims.But Ball’s gilded life in the top echelons of the Church of England came crashing down in October 2015, when he was jailed for sexual offences against boys as young as 15, dating from the late Seventies to the early Nineties.His trial heard how he chose young priests to share his bed, forced them to take cold showers while he watched, and got one man to roll naked in the snow before towelling him dry and beating him until he bled.Ball is now a free man living in Somerset, having served half of his 32-month sentence. His rise to power began in 1960 when he established a monastery in Gloucestershire with twin brother Michael, also a bishop.Ball became known for showing “favouritism” to novice monks, and he embraced the opportunity to speak in schools. It later emerged that was where he met five of his victims. As his influence grew within the Church he constructed a powerful social network, regularly dining with Margaret Thatcher at posh London hotel The Savoy, often in his monk’s habit.When he became Bishop of Gloucester in 1992, it was not long before he used his position to get close to Charles, whose Highgrove estate came under his diocese. This friendship was tested that December when Ball was arrested for the first time for gross indecency.One of his trainees, 16-year-old Neil Todd, alleged that Ball had forced him to rehearse “penitential psalms” naked in the middle of the night so he could “feel the cold”.Ball made him take cold showers and expressed a desire to whip Neil so badly his body would “bear the marks”.Another six young victims came forward with similar stories after Neil reported the abuse to the police.As part of Ball’s 2015 trial, the court heard that, backed by “Cabinet ministers, the Royal Family, MPs, JPs and a lord”, he escaped with a caution over the 1992 allegations.He quit as Bishop of Gloucester and settled into retirement in a Duchy of Cornwall property rented to him by Prince Charles in the village of Aller, Somerset. He was still allowed to officiate at services, including more than 20 at schools.According to an independent report commissioned by Archbishop Justin Welby and published last year by Dame Moira Gibb, Ball’s brother, Bishop Michael Ball, wrote at the end of 1992 to Lord Carey, saying his brother was receiving support from prominent figures.It emerged that Lord Carey had lobbied police and prosecutors on Ball’s behalf, while treating the disgraced bishop to a holiday and a £12,500 pay-off.Dame Moira wrote: “Peter Ball abused many boys and men. That is shocking in itself but is compounded by the failure of the Church to respond appropriately to his misconduct.”But it was Ball’s friendship with “confidant” Charles that is seen as most alarming.As well as regularly corresponding, praying together and attending Charles’s 2005 nuptials, he was invited to address mourners at the funeral of Major Bruce Shand, the Duchess of Cornwall’s father, in 2006.Lord Carey retired in 2002 and was succeeded by Rowan Williams, who in 2007 announced the Church would investigate historic sex cases. A 2008 Church review of Ball’s case found seven letters of complaint received by Lambeth Palace in 1992 had been ignored, with revelations of nakedness, masturbation and assault.These were disclosed to police and Operation Dunhill was launched in July 2012. After surviving two previous suicide attempts, victim Neil Todd took his own life, aged 38, after this new investigation began. Ball finally appeared at the Old Bailey in 2015. The trial heard from 18 victims but it is believed there were more than 100.Ball was jailed after admitting to two counts of indecent assault and a charge of misconduct in public office as part of a plea bargain He was released in February last year, and moved back to Aller.It is unclear whether he still lives in the rented Duchy property. A week-long examination of the case will take place next month, held by the IICSA.On Wednesday, counsel to the inquiry Fiona Scolding QC confirmed witness statements had been requested from Prince Charles and his private secretary.Charles’s name is in the clear — but is his conscience?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: amazon prime plays the premier league game
story: The company puts great store by encouraging more and more people to sign up for its Prime package, which involves paying an annual fee in exchange for next-day delivery on purchases, as well as television and film content.And these matches will only be available to people with a Prime account.It was the same logic that led Amazon to sign up the Top Gear team - an eye-catching deal, that can be marketed heavily and bring in new subscribers.Expect a big campaign to persuade you to spend most of Boxing Day watching football with the family, which may delight some and horrify others.Amazon gets to put its toe in the water, which has led plenty to speculate that, next time round, the company will return with plans to buy a huge chunk of rights. Right now, I doubt that.The billions of pounds that it would take to buy the British television rights simply wouldn't return an investment for them, Google, Apple, or any other global tech player.What might attract them more are the international rights.That's also the area with the greatest scope for growth and, by coincidence, today was also the day when the Premier League announced it was changing the way that the revenue would be divided up from its global deals.More will now go the big six clubs, who have successfully argued that they provide the panache and stardust that attracts viewers, from Thailand to Tajikistan.That's a decision with the potential to shake top-flight football even more profoundly than the arrival of Amazon.

title: armed forces must do more to promote women into senior military positions
story: As of October 2017 women represented only 10.3% of the regular military - that equates to just over 15,000 females.The figures are even worse among senior ranks: just 3.6% of the most senior roles are occupied by women.During his tenure as chief of the defence staff, Air Chief Marshal Peach has supported an initiative allowing men or women to swap easily between the regular and reserve forces without any penalty to their career path - allowing them to better manage family demands.At present, more women are leaving the military than joining it.He explained: "What it means is that you can join the armed forces as a man or woman and you can move in and out of regular and reserve service, and take a break for whatever family reason and then come back and be advanced and promoted."That is quite radical, in fact many of our friends and allies overseas are looking at this policy.In 2016, the UK lifted the ban on women fighting in close combat roles, meaning that women can now serve in every area of the armed forces.Sir Stuart will become chairman of NATO's Military Council, making him the most senior military officer in the Alliance.The former RAF fast jet pilot became the first head of the UK's Armed Forces not to be privately educated when he was appointed by the prime minister in 2016. His story is rare in a military dominated by officers from private education."I'm very proud of the fact that I grew up in the West Midlands and went to a normal school. Actually it was a grammar school at the time and is now an academy."I then went to the University of Sheffield, I was the first person in my family to go to university, and I then joined the Royal Air Force on what was then known as an air cadetship, 44 years ago."The armed forces, in particular the army, have been criticised for not doing enough to attract talent from a more diverse background.
